learned_patterns.description: Diagram-first documentation: always produce a Mermaid diagram before writing explanatory prose
learned_patterns.notes: Constitution Article IX mandates diagram-first. A sequence diagram for a webhook flow communicates in 30 seconds what 500 words of prose takes 3 minutes to convey.

learned_patterns.description: API documentation must include: endpoint description, request schema, response schema, error codes, and curl example — no exceptions
learned_patterns.notes: Incomplete API docs are worse than no docs — they mislead developers. stablecoin-gateway API.md is the reference standard for all API documentation.

learned_patterns.description: ADR format: Context → Decision → Alternatives Considered (with before/after diagrams) → Consequences
learned_patterns.notes: Alternatives considered section is the most valuable part of an ADR — it prevents future agents from re-litigating settled decisions. Always include at least 2 alternatives.

learned_patterns.description: README must have: business context (not just setup), architecture diagram, getting started that actually works, and API overview
learned_patterns.notes: Found 3 READMEs that were just npm install instructions with no context. Rewrote with business context + architecture diagram. Future agents oriented 4x faster.

deliverables: README.md with business context, C4 diagram, getting started, SDK quickstart

common_mistakes.mistake: Writing documentation that describes what code does, not why it exists
common_mistakes.impact: Future agents had to read code to understand business context — docs provided no additional value
common_mistakes.prevention: Start every section by answering: Why does this exist? What problem does it solve? Then explain how.
common_mistakes.checklist_item: Does this documentation answer WHY before HOW?

common_mistakes.mistake: Producing diagrams without testing they render correctly in GitHub Markdown
common_mistakes.impact: Mermaid syntax error caused blank diagram in GitHub — agents saw nothing
common_mistakes.prevention: Paste all Mermaid diagrams into mermaid.live to validate before committing
common_mistakes.checklist_item: Have I validated all Mermaid diagrams in mermaid.live?

preferred_approaches.approach: C4 Level 1 (Context) → C4 Level 2 (Container) → C4 Level 3 (Component) → Sequence diagrams for key flows → ER diagram for schema. Diagrams first, prose second.
preferred_approaches.reason: Progressive detail lets readers drill down to their level of interest. Diagrams communicate structure faster than text.
preferred_approaches.example: muaththir architecture.md: 8 diagrams across 4 C4 levels — orientation time cut from 45 minutes to 10 minutes

preferred_approaches.approach: Method + Path → Description (one sentence) → Authentication requirements → Request body (TypeScript interface + example JSON) → Response (TypeScript interface + example JSON) → Error codes table → curl example
preferred_approaches.reason: Consistent format makes API docs predictable and scannable
preferred_approaches.example: stablecoin-gateway API.md: followed this format for all 12 endpoints — developers onboarded 3x faster

efficiency_improvements.old_approach: Write diagram, commit, see result in GitHub
efficiency_improvements.new_approach: Validate in mermaid.live before committing — catches syntax errors instantly
